Award.AwardTitle: Conference: 2017 Gordon Research Seminar on Nucleic Acids at University of New England in Biddeford, ME

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support attendance by graduate students and postdoctoral researchers at the Gordon Research Seminar at the University of New England, Biddeford, ME on June 3-4, 2017. The meeting is organized and chaired by two graduate students. The format of the meeting is a combination of talks and posters, which will promote scientific exchange in both formal and informal settings. Two keynote lectures will be featured, one from a leading researcher in the field and one focused on practical aspects of grant writing. There will be ample opportunity for sharing latest research results and for exploring collaborative possibilities.

The field of nucleic acids research is diverse, encompassing research related to the biology of both RNA and DNA. Recent advances in the field reflect this diversity and will be highlighted in this conference, which will bring together scientists who do not often have the opportunity to interact and learn from each other. Among the topics for discussion will be discovery and investigation of an expanding array of non-coding RNAs, as well as new technologies that are being applied to probe reactions and interactions in the molecular machines responsible for diverse processes, including mRNA splicing, protein synthesis, DNA replication, and recombination. Cutting-edge or late-breaking research will be highlighted in short talks chosen from the abstracts and in posters. The primary purposes of this conference are to provide a venue for scientific exchange of new research results and ideas among young researchers, to foster learning about emerging paradigms and how they contribute to future goals for research on RNA and DNA biology, and to encourage career development of a new generation of nucleic acids researchers, including those who are underrepresented in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The first biennial Nucleic Acids Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) was held at the University of New England, Biddeford, ME from Saturday, June 3, 2017 to Sunday, June 4, 2017. This two day meeting provided a unique forum for junior scientists to present and exchange new data and cutting edge ideas on the biology and chemistry of nucleic acids, immediately prior to the attached Nucleic Acids Gordon Research Conference (GRC).

 

The 2017 Nucleic Acids GRS covered many aspects of intellectually interesting and contemporarily important topics, including CRISPR biology, RNA processing and disease, DNA replication dynamics, and telomere biology, as well as several novel methods, including cryoEM, single molecule analysis, ribosome profiling, and RNA-seq approaches. The meeting was well-attended by 42 young researchers from United States and the rest of the world. To promote participation of each attendee, the program included 19 short talks by graduate students and postdocs, as well as 7 discussion leaders in four sessions. In addition, there was ample opportunity for extensive interactions for each participant at two GRS poster sessions and four poster sessions in the following GRC conference. The format of the GRS meeting provided an inclusive, collegial atmosphere and allowed all the attendees to present their results as talks or as posters, and to routinely include a significant amount of unpublished results.

 

The 2017 Nucleic Acids GRS featured an ethnically and geographically diverse group of attendee and speakers. The meeting recruited 32 participants from 13 U.S. states, and other countries including one attendee from China, one from the Czech Republic, one from France, two from Israel, two from the United Kingdom, and one from Uruguay. Moreover, the meeting was gender-balanced, 20/42 attendees, 7/19 speakers, and 3/7 discussion leaders were female. In addition, the GRS featured two keynote speakers: one well known mid-level woman professor, highlighted her experience in making career transitions from a graduate student to postdoc, and from a postdoc to junior faculty; and an NSF program director described important considerations in fellowship application and grant writing strategies.

 

In summary, the 2017 Nucleic Acids GRS brought together a diverse group of junior scientists who worked on a variety of aspects of DNA and RNA biology. This seminar offered a golden opportunity for the education and training of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in a setting that is ideal for scientific discussion, platform presentation practice, exchange of new ideas, and networking, and promoted more involvement in the following Nucleic Acids GRC. The reviews of the meeting were very positive.
